_exec_summary.SummaryText:
HARVESTLAND COOPERATIVE

HWY. 68 WEST

WABASSO, MN. 56293





FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT: Dan Mathiowetz, PLANT MANAGER



RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1. THE HARVESTLAND POLICY



THE OWNERS,MANAGEMENT AND EMPLOYEES OF HARVESTLAND ARE COMMITED TO THE PREVENTION OF ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF AHNYDROUS AMMONIA.IF AN ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SHOULD OCCUR, HARVESTLAND IS PREPARED TO WORK WITH LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT, OR OTHER AUTHORITIES, TO MITIGATE ANY RELEASE AND MINIMIZE THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE TO PEOPLE AND THE ENVIROMENT.



2. FACILITY INFORMATION



-THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY AT HARVESTLAND IS THE STORAGE AND BLENDING OF FERTILIZERS FOR SALE TO FARMERS.



-AHNYDROUS AMMONIA IS RECEIVED, STORED, AND DISTRIBUTED FOR DIRECT APPLICATION TO AREA FIELDS FOR CROP PRODUCTION NUTRIENTS.



-THE MAXIMUM QUANTITY STORED WOULD BE 227,000 POUNDS IN OUR 30,000 GALLON STORAGE TANK AND ALL ROLLING STOCK.



3.THE ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



HARVESTLAND HAS IMPLEMENTED THE PROVISIONS OF "SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE STORAGE AND HANDLING OF AHNTDRUOS AMMONIA, K-61.1",PUBLISHED BY THE AMERICAN NATIONAL STANDARDS INSTITUTE,INC., AND THE STANDARDS OF THE U.S. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYGROUS AMMONIA.



4. THE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



THERE HAS BEEN ZERO ACCIDENTAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IN THE LAST 5 YEARS.



5. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.



HARVESTLAND HAS:



A WRITTEN EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OSHA STANDARD, 29 CFR 1910.38.AND



PROVIDED STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES THE EMERGENCYPLANNING AND COMMUNITY RIGHT-TO-KNOW INFORMATION AS REQUIRED UNDER SARA TITLE III (EPCRA). AND



COORDINATED WITH LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS.



6.PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



SAFETY IMPROVEMENT IS AN ON-GOING PROCESS AT HARVESTLAND. PEROIDIC EVALUATIONS ARE PERFORMED TO ASSESS THE MAINTENANCE OF SAFE CONDITIONS. THERE ARE NO ADDITIONAL SPECIFIC ANHYDROUS AMMONIA SAFETY

RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION AT THIS TIME.



Dan Mathiowetz
